movieReview: Still so good, perfect "i'm sick on the couch" viewing
Once you pop, you can't stop.
I didn't think we were gonna close out the series before we left Michigan but Rita insisted.  Now we are ready for Chapter 4
I don't think i've seen this since it was contemporary, and it remains quite good.  It was interesting to watch knowing the twists (even if it took me awhile to remember all of them)

movieTitle: Glass Onion: A Knives Out Mystery
movieReview: Not up to KNIVES OUT but very fun and quite good
I think 3 hosts are too many, but it was worth the experiment

I hadn't seen this in like 25-30 years.  I've always referred to it as the "3rd greatest concert film of all time", behind STOP MAKING SENSE and IN CASE YOU DIDN'T FEEL LIKE SHOWING UP (LIVE).  I obviously know there's a bit of controversy over my #2, but after seeing TLW again tonight I feel even firmer about my rankings.  TLW is a great concert, but as a film it is kind of puzzling.  Why is the Emmylou Harris number not live?  Why, immediately after that, does Scorcese et al show the beginning of a Garth Hudson organ solo just to abruptly cut it off.... This combined with some real other curious choices, like some visible zooms and editing including the artifice of interviews makes me wonder what Scorcese was thinking.  Maybe it was just the blow.
I thought this was gonna be schlockier and more horror than it was.  I mean it was plenty schlocky, but it was also more sci-fi and fairly tight.
Booooooooooooooooring
Totally forgot about this story and I’m not sure I knew the follow up about his crime

While at some level this is a very dark comedy, it is definitely not the kind of movie you should recommend as such.  It was very good, but bleak as fuck, and my comedic expectations probably caused it to take a bit longer for me to settle in.
Booooooring
Even lesser Jackass is great.  I could watch this crew forever.
Hell yeah this is a solid as fuck b action movie
Still wonderful.  Don’t know what else I can say.

movieTitle: An Ostrich Told Me the World Is Fake and I Think I Believe It
movieReview: This was ok, but the whole framing device of showing the film on the video village monitor was stupid and annoyed me more as the movie progressed.  Also some version of this movie has been made like 300 times.  This doesn't really bring anything new.
If you told me I could fall asleep during a 7 minute short I'd have called bullshit.  But here we are.
This was the nominated short I liked the most of the group.  Short, told a little story with no dialogue, looked pretty.

movieTitle: The Boy, the Mole, the Fox and the Horse
movieReview: Trash. Looked nice but waaaaay too long and dialogue which seemed like a lightning bolt hit a Hallmark card.  Trite aphorisms galore.  The audience had the giddies by the end of it because it was all so eye-rollingly saccharine.
This was the "funnest" of the 5 animated shorts in the package this year.  Played with style, told a nice story, a bit long but ok.
I had never seen this one, but after visiting Quebec and staying in the Frontenac we felt it was required.  As expected, solid but not amazing.
Does what it says on the tin
I had forgotten more about the show than I remembered, but this was a nice little crime thriller.  could have shed about 10m
Familiy wanted to watch this and who am I to stop them.  Still very good.
Family also wanted to watch this, so we did.  Still fun.
Wow. Not sure why I thought I should watch this but it was the turd everyone suggested it was

movieTitle: Stand By for Failure: A Documentary About Negativland
movieReview: This is the second Negativland doc in the past few years and this one is definitely more abstract, which fits the subject. Good for fans of the band, likely inscrutable for everyone else
Coco hadn't seen this and I enjoyed it the first time around so we watched it tonight.  Was still pretty good!

A bit too long, but still tons of fun.  One of the remarkable things about this movie is that even when its "swarms of bad guys vs John Wick", the movie gives you enough to hang on to so you can actually keep track of the swarms of bad guys and feel progression in the fight.  Marvel could really take some notes.
This was a perfectly adequate, generic fantasy movie, but it really had little to do with D&D in the grand scheme of things beyond some fanservice-y placements...
This was fairly engaging for a slasher.

I discovered Spalding gray in college, and I’ve always had a very soft spot for him in my heart and it was great to see this documentary couple together from archive footage. I think I’ll revisit his films.
A prequel to X, this was a bit long but Mia Goth's performance, and especially her monologue in the final act, really make this film.
This was an interesting 1 hour doc about a subject I didn't know anything about:  The men responsible for assembling the footage shown at Nuremberg.
This was a super interesting doc about a bullshit artist who also saved many lives.
this was ok, but it was a worse version of WWDITS imho
A pretty big turd

movieTitle: Love to Love You, Donna Summer
movieReview: This was OK, but it dragged a bit for me...  There seemed to be some connective tissue missing, often I felt unmoored in time.  It also did this thing where it algorithmically animated still images with blinks, smiles and head turns.  It was uncanny valley for me. #IFFBoston
This was a fun short about dreams and reality. #IFFBoston
Fun with a surprising twist. #IFFBoston
A good premise that really went nowhere or seemed to have anything to say. #IFFBoston
This felt like something some buddies threw together. #IFFBoston
Very fun-but-dark Quebecois short. #IFFBoston
It's not too soon. #IFFBoston
A highlight of this shorts package, a down on his luck actor starts working birthdays and life intervenes.. #IFFBoston
Lots of fun, following a frustrating, difficult protagonist. Bonus points for being 80m! #IFFBoston
First non-virtual date post-COVID goes sideways. #IFFBoston
Pretty animated short memorializing the post first-date glow. #IFFBoston
Funny short where two friends realize their double-date is a bust. #IFFBoston
Sweet short about an older transplant to the US trying to make sense of her new life. #IFFBoston

movieTitle: Still: A Michael J. Fox Movie
movieReview: I almost skipped this as I assumed I "knew what it was" but I was wrong. This was excellent, and you should check it out when it drops on Apple TV+ in a few weeks. #IFFBoston
A "High Concept" sci-fi comedy that's weird as heck but fun. #IFFBoston
A young girl on her first day of school gets ready.  #IFFBoston

movieTitle: Wherever The War, Whoever The Enemy
movieReview: Repurposed from a US Army ad, this confronts the US self-image of it's military machine.  #IFFBoston
A bit long at 30m, but an interesting look into the life of two people on Hengam Island.  #IFFBoston
I found this a bit frustrating, but that is likely baggage from my own perspective of an atheist who doesn't believe in burial.  #IFFBoston
A contemporary look at a musician turned politician in Uganda and his struggles against the current regime.  Fascinating, keep an eye out for this National Geographic doc.  #IFFBoston
A refugee Afghan translator finds her life and relationships in the United States.  Starring a first time actor who kills it. #IFFBoston
I think you'll really like this if you are familiar with the band, but I found it a bit repetitive. #IFFBoston
A near-future speculative exploration of an aging population. Strong start that peters a bit, but still interesting. #IFFBoston
A highlight of this year's festival, this doc about the decline and value of clubs and groups is tight and convincing. #IFFBoston
I'm not sure if it was festival fatigue or the film itself, but despite the subject matter which interested me I found myself dozing off during the first half of this film. #IFFBoston

movieTitle: Never Be A Punching Bag for Nobody
movieReview: An exciting debut feature from Naomi Yang as she accidentally takes boxing lessons and also explores the history of East Boston. #IFFBoston

A great look into the contemporary Boston music scene, focusing on the struggle of non cis-het male musicians.  I really appreciated how the filmmaker didn't break the discussions into explicit "sections" and instead make it feel like a natural flow from topic to topic despite dozens of interview subjects. #IFFBoston
This was OK, but it felt a little long and it also seemed to gloss over much of her personal life in favor of her career. #IFFBoston
This was quite good, avoiding many of the tropes of this sort of film. #IFFBoston
A gripping look into the lives of several trans women who are also sex workers. #IFFBoston
This was excellent, it got “tech” right (for Hollywood) and felt breezy for 2 hours. #iffboston
This was a beautiful film about 3 people managing the intersection of their relationships over the course of decades.   Subtle and grownup and touching.  Wonderful way to end a wonderful #IFFBoston
Believe it or not, I’ve never seen this it’s always been on my list, but I never got around to it. It’s obviously quite good and quite striking.
I didn't really give a shit about anyone in this movie.  It also felt strangely separate from the MCU...
The first Ant-Man was one of my favorites in the MCU, the second less so, but this one was a muddy mess.
This was fun and the cast was great.
This was fine, one of the better Marvel films in awhile, but it wasn't particularly special.
I hadn’t seen this in ages. It’s still great, tho it now carries so much baggage from idiots misinterpreting it.

I had somehow never saw this, the only
Fincher I had missed.  Quite good.
This was the most grounded FCU film in ages, and it was not grounded at all.
I hadn’t seen the OG in ages. Holds up!

What a turd.... This was John Woo when he was at his "John Woo-iest", indulging in all of his tropes to the fullest...  The unnecessary and visually ugly overcranked slowmo was the most egregious.  The MI films to come before and after it all, certainly, have their over the top moments, but they still manage to feel grounded and less visually ugly.
This was a glaring hole in my classic film punchcard, and I'm glad to have finally watched it.  It was very good, which I guess should be obvious given it's reputation...
A perfectly fine, fun little movie.
Hadn’t seen this in forever and never on the big screen. On 35mm!!  So great
In-laws hadn’t seen this yet so we watched this. Still great.
And lo and behold a few days later we are watching the OG as my nieces hadn’t seen it.
Wes Anderson buy a different Wes Anderson. Still very mannered, but also more vague.
This was perfectly fun, but the scientist bad guy was WAAAAAAY too over the top lol

movieTitle: Indiana Jones and the Dial of Destiny
movieReview: This was *fine*...  It was way too long, basically every action set piece should have been shorter, and the opening train scene should have been waaaay shorter (or perhaps removed altogether).   If it were 90m it'd be great.   But way better than CRYSTAL SKULL and perhaps the second-best Indy sequel (but admittedly, I'm not as fond of LAST CRUSADE as most).
This was a fun movie that I think may have gotten lost in early quar.
a collection of video essays about the relationship between David Lynch and The Wizard of Oz. John Waters was the highlight
Took forever to get started but was fine. Definitely had fun moments
This was a very good one, despite some JJ Abrams bullshit

movieTitle: Mission: Impossible - Dead Reckoning Part One
movieReview: Too long, but overall a good, fun ride.
Despite everything, this was actually fun.

Bryan Murray mentioned this in a chat at the UFM booth at NICE, A FEST, and it sounded up my alley.  A doc about a series of shows in the desert or at sea featuring bands like EINSTURZENDE NEUBATEN, MINUTEMEN, and SONIC YOUTH?  hell yeah
This was a solid overview of the subject, though the Bobby Broccoli (lol) youtube series went more in depth
I guess I never really thought about how briefly Wham existed.  They felt so big in my memory
This was more charming and funny than it had any right to be.  You hear about a movie based on a doll and you assume it will be trash.  It was not at all.
This was fun and entertaining but obviously heightened
This was quite good, but I'm not exactly rushing out to see it again.  The timeline seemed a bit unnecessarily confusing, as if Nolan is afraid of making a straightforward, linear story

movieTitle: Hollywood Dreams & Nightmares: The Robert Englund Story
movieReview: Your standard modern schlocky fandom/crowdfunded doc. But Robert is so charming I stuck with it.
Fox did this movie dirty by dumping it on Hulu.  This would have been great in a theatre.

movieTitle: Squaring the Circle (The Story of Hipgnosis)
movieReview: Great retrospective of Hipgnosis. Great complement to the book from a few years ago, “Vinyl. Album. Cover. Art.”
Still great
This movie rips.  It was a riot and so much fun.  I'm glad I waited to see it on the big screen with an audience.
This was ok. Not as good as I remember the “original”
Today is the 40th anniversary of its release (in Canada). Still great!
Watched this again with Corinna.... My original criticisms all still stand, but it is a fairly fun movie.
Knew basically nothing about this movie, but have learned to trust The Brattle... That trust was rewarded, a sweet fun movie that screamed 80s without being obnoxious about it.

This was pretty surprising and engaging until the very end.  I liked the style and some of the surprises, but the conclusion felt fairly “standard horror” to me. Still not bad, and great compared to most modern horror

movieTitle: Beats, Rhymes & Life: The Travels of A Tribe Called Quest
movieReview: Excellent.

I hadn't heard of this before today, and being able to see a modern print of this movie I had never heard of was intriguing.  It was good, not great, but kind of puzzling... I heard it described as a "black comedy", and while there were some laughs, I definitely didn't see it as a black comedy...

movieTitle: Évocateur: The Morton Downey Jr. Movie
movieReview:
Lmao I have no recollection of seeing this before.  But I apparently saw it almost 10 years ago when it first came out.

Someone mentioned Morton Downey Jr. the other day and I was reminded of him, so I checked this out.
An excellent doc that wasn’t a hagiography.

movieTitle: The Angry Black Girl and Her Monster
movieReview: Well shot, and punched above its budget, but ultimately kinda mid.

Third times a charm. I thought Covid was gonna prevent me from seeing this anniversary edition in the theater but the Somerville held it over for an extra week so I snuck in at the last minute. This is still excellent.
Ok. Lesser than WOLF OF WALL STREET or THE BIG SHORT but still fun
Full disclosure: I was strangely exhausted and was largely asleep for the first 20m of this movie.  That said, once I came to, I enjoyed the story.  I look forward to watching it again when I'm awake
I enjoyed this quite a bit.  It was an absurdist take on technology and romance... A study of how we've let technology moderate our personal relationships.
This was not for me at all.
This had some beautiful moments but the story structure didn’t work for me.
This was exactly what you want it to be.

movieTitle: All Dirt Roads Taste of Salt
movieReview: This was not for me at all...  Too meditative and abstract.... Long, lingering shots on hands or backs of heads.... Non-linear with almost no dialogue.    Thought about leaving.
This was a pretty (not happy) little story that I enjoyed...
I loved this...  Followed a quiet, solitary man through several days... Each a bit of a vignette, but all adding up to a sum.  Beautifully shot and acted.
Beautiful film both thematically and visually...  Great composition w/o being showy, really made you feel like you were watching actual cooks...
Really humanizes Rob and Fab and I totally understand the trap they fell in to, even if they made tons of bad decisions after signing the contract
Exactly the right amount of dumb B-movie fun I needed tonight
I love it when Fincher gets a little B.  This was fun.
Perfectly fine biopic, surprisingly understated for Coppola.

movieTitle: Batali: The Fall of a Superstar Chef
movieReview: I knew about the Boston allegations but I didn’t really know about everything prior

movieTitle: Pete Doherty, Who Killed My Son?
movieReview: I believe that something criminal occurred, but this was pretty tabloidy in production and structure
This was ok.
This was a great look back at a wildly important and excellent game.
This was a good movie, but a bit of a confounding one. There were times where it seemed to be comedic, but I now think it was to keep you guessing.

movieTitle: Journey to EPCOT Center: A Symphonic History
movieReview: This was an interesting experimental documentary, using largely historical footage and images along with a original score to tell the story of Epcot Center
This is a compelling story but a small story.  Almost nobody will ever encounter Michael Organ yet somehow the story the filmmaker relays is fascinating.
I had forgotten a ton about the original, but this was alright….  I didn’t remember it had gotten Covid’ed, wonder how it would have done otherwise
Waaaaaay too much Gene Simmons.  Otherwise was interesting.
This was an equalizer film.
This was just as lovely as I remembered....   I saw this so much as a kid but according to my records I haven't seen it since at least 2003...  I still remembered almost every line verbatim..
This was a movie
I remain fascinated and disgusted by GG Allin but
This was good.... Strangely, even at 2.5 hours there were times it felt rushed.... I mean, probably not a surprise given the massive subject
Solid doc. Brought together a host of various stories and anecdotes I’ve heard over the years. Could have shed about 15m
Believe it or not, I had never gotten around to seeing this.  It is, no surprise, quite good.
This was pretty good, a shame it was straight to Netflix, I think it would have been really good in a crowd
Hadn’t seen this since it was new. It was fine.
Never gets old.
MOTHAFUCKA IM GONNA KILL YA. IM GONNA FUCKIN COOK YA. AND IM GONNA FUCKIN EAT YA
I hadn’t heard about this at all, but Corinna got the Blu-ray for her parents for Christmas so we watched it. Perfectly serviceable historical film.

movieTitle: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes
movieReview: This was fine, but unnecessary.

movieTitle: Indiana Jones and the Dial of Destiny
movieReview: Rita and Kim were interested in seeing this, and Corinna hadn't either.  The opening sequence remains mediocre and ghoulish, but once we are past that it is a perfectly acceptable Indiana Jones movie.
